required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: MigALastat Therapy Adherence Among FABRY Patients: A Prospective Multicentral Observational Study
clinical_study.official_title: A Structured Survey Among Fabry Patients With a Focus on Adherence to Therapy, Quality of Life and Pain Control

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates adherence to the oral chaperone therapy migalastat in patients with Fabry disease.

detailed_description.textblock:
Fabry disease is a rare disease and part of the group of lysosomal storage disorders. Since 2016, chaperone therapy as a new therapeutic approach is available.
This study is a prospective cohort study and observes patients under therapy with migalastat. This study is suggested to help estimating the adherence of the oral therapy.
All patients in treatment with migalastat in the Fabry Center Wuerzburg (FAZiT) and selected patients of other cooperating Fabry Centers are included in this study if informed consent is provided.

primary_outcome.measure: Adherence to oral therapy with migalastat according to Morisky Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of inclusion up to104 weeks (2 years)
primary_outcome.description: Pharmacological adherence according to Morisky Score. (Concurrent and Predictive Validity of a Self-Reported Measure of Medication Adherence Author(s): Donald E. Morisky, Lawrence W. Green and David M. Levine Source: Medical Care, Vol. 24, No. 1 (Jan., 1986), pp. 67-74 Published by: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins Stable URL: http://www.jstor.org/stable/3764638) "Concurrent and Predictive Validity of a Self-reported Measure of Medication Adherence", established by Donald E. Morisky, consists of 4 questions. Every question can be answered either with "yes" (0 points) or "no" (1 point), leading to a summed score between 0 and 4. 0 is the worst outcome while 4 is the best possible outcome (very good adherence). This part of the score can be used without special permission (Author was contacted via E-Mail).

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life according to SF-36 and Wuerzburg pain questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From date of inclusion up to104 weeks (2 years)
secondary_outcome.description: Change of quality of life under migalastat therapy according to SF-36 and Wuerzburg pain questionnaire. Short Form (36), abbreviated SF-36, is a disease-specific measurement tool for increasing the health-related quality of life. The SF-36 is composed of eight scale-valued domains that correspond to the weighted sums of answers in each section. The range of values of each scale is 0-100 under the assumption that each question has the same weight. A score of 0 is the worst outcome (maximum disability) and a score of 100 is the best outcome (no disability). The eight domains of the SF-36 are vitality, physical functioning, bodily pain, general health perceptions, physical role functioning, emotional role functioning, social role functioning and mental health.

other_outcome.measure: Pain according to SF-36 and Wuerzburg pain questionnaire
other_outcome.time_frame: From date of inclusion up to104 weeks (2 years)
other_outcome.description: Change of pain under migalastat therapy according to SF-36 and Wuerzburg pain questionnaire. The Wuerzburg pain questionnaire was created by Üçeyler et al. In this questionnaire, the patient's pain phenotype is characterized with questions about the presence of 1) permanent pain, 2) pain attacks, 3) pain crisis, and 4) evoked pain (by touching a cold or warm object or by pressure) in childhood and/or adulthood with the response options Yes, No, or Don't know. Other criteria can be found in the publication (Üçeyler N, Ganendiran S, Kramer D, Sommer C. Characterization of pain in fabry disease. Clin J Pain. 2014 Oct;30(10):915-20.).

study_pop.textblock: The study population includes every patient with Fabry disease and therapy who is seen in the FAZiT Wuerzburg. Limitation is a therapy with migalastat.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fabry disease (genetically confirmed)
- Signed informed consent
- 18 years and older
Exclusion Criteria:
- No informed consent
- Withdrawal of informed consent
